results.title: [Stelarc: Stretched Skin No.4 Munich 1977]
results.brief_description:
This video footage is of a suspension performance entitled “Event for Stretched Skin No. 4” that took place at the Art Academy in Munich, Germany on 8 August 1977.

As the name suggests, this was Stelarc’s fourth suspension performance, in which the artist’s body is suspended in space by a series of hooks inserted into the skin. The artist began performing these durational performances in Japan in 1976; this was his first international performance.

In the video, we see the hooks being pierced into the skin across the back and front of the body. The body is then suspended upside down from a sculptural structure made out of logs of wood. The body hangs with arms outstretched in front of the windows of the Art Academy, showing Munich in the background. The performance is observed by a team of assistants, photographers and a small audience.

This performance was originally filmed on 1/2 inch videotape.

results.title: Hungry Horace for ZX Spectrum
results.creator_credit: Melbourne House, Psion Software and Laser Beam (Beam Software)
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette and cover in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
Hungry Horace offered gameplay based of the popular arcade game Pac-Man. It was celebrated as the first arcade game for the Spectrum. It was one of the few Spectrum games that were also available in ROM format. It formed part of the Horace series, which included Horace Goes Skiing and Horace and the Spiders and the unpublished Horace to the Rescue.

Horace is a blue blob with arms and legs, who wanders around a maze, picking the flowers, collecting fruit and avoiding the park guards, who are out to capture him. He is able to momentarily scare the guards, making them vulnerable, by ringing a bell in the maze. If Horace is able to escape capture and leave the maze, he moves to the next, more challenging level.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/hungry-horace-orginal-spectrum/

Last accessed: 17/05/2021

Original game developed by Beam Software and Psion Software. Published in 1982 by Melbourne House.

results.title: You and I, Horizontal II
results.material_description: computer, computer script, projector and  haze machine
results.brief_description:
Step into a dark haze-filled room to interact with the power of projected light. Transforming a beam of light into a three-dimensional sculpture, Anthony McCall’s ‘You and I, Horizontal II’ (2006) is an Australian premiere.

The pioneering work of British-born artist Anthony McCall occupies a space between sculpture, cinema, performance and drawing. McCall was one of the first visual artists to experiment with spatial film and temporal sculpture, emerging in the mid 1970s with the ‘Solid Light’ film series - works that used a 16mm projector to project cones of light through smoke or haze filled rooms. His work attracted renewed attention in the 1990s, when spatial installations once again became a popular and critical tendency in contemporary art. He now uses digital projection and complex graphic software systems to capture the most basic sensory element of the moving image: the projection of light.

results.title: Flamingo Park
results.creator_credit: Clytie Jessop, Women's Film Fund (Australia) and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Shows the works of two artistic and talented Australian fashion designers. Jenny Kee’s colourful designs are inspired by the tones of the bush, birds and flora, whilst Linda Jackson’s inspiration comes from the ocean and the sealife. Jenny’s designs are made up into outstandingly colourful handknitted garments, whilst Linda uses chiffons, cottons and appliqued designs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Clytie Jessop, Women’s Film Fund (Australia) and Australian Film Commission

results.title: Abakanowicz in Australia
results.creator_credit: Christopher McGill, Malcolm Otton, Crafts Council of Australia and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Polish artist Magdalena Abakanowicz prepares for an exhibition of her work in Australia. We see her exhibits of large rope, hessian and string three-dimensional forms. She comments upon her intended purpose in working with such materials. Narrated by Margaret Throsby.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher McGill, Malcolm Otton, Crafts Council of Australia and Film Australia

results.title: Street XRays
results.brief_description:
Drawing on the NSW Police Department’s photographic archive, Street X-Rays interprets approximately sixty crime scenes from the 1950s, to evoke the power of the continuing life of the past in our ordinary, everyday places.

The police images are placed beside contemporary footage recorded in the same location, from the same camera position. Each screen holds two moments in time, two disparate attempts to interrogate a location. Texts from police records and the artist’s enigmatic narrative prompts punctuate this essentially visual dialogue. The effects of time linger in each scene and across the entire imaginative space of this half-historical/half-mythical city that is evoked in the installation space.

I’ve tried to conjure a place that’s haunted by persistent little pulses of history. I hope viewers feel as if they’ve wandered into a vaguely familiar ‘otherworld’ that’s being buffeted by a kind of ‘spirit weather’ - Ross Gibson.

Taken from PROOF exhibition 2004

results.title: lifeSigns: eco-system of signs and symbols
results.material_description: video, interactive software, computers, monitors, projection, PVC stands, colour and audio
results.brief_description: An interactive digital networked work where participants play selected emotions as game identities in any manner they choose, the results seen in a fluid projection onto a mounted floor screen between the game terminals in the form of a dynamic and fluctuating virtual realm. Through playing the game, then, the participant contributes to building an ecosystem of sentiments at play and in conflict with one another. The ‘life signs’ chosen by participants are generated as three dimensional icons that construct an evolving virtual language of symbols, sounds and behaviours in interaction with the audiences’ collective participation. The floor projection represents the fluctuating results of the networked game, while an immersive soundscape simultaneously responds to the ever-changing game narrative.The more participants, the greater the intensity of image and sound. The process of the audiences use of and play with sentiments and emotions thus becomes the foundation in constant flux for the visual and aural world that the audience engages with in the installation.
